Post Text: There's no doubt that it takes some exceptional qualities to get to the top. Especially when on the way up, a woman will be dogged by charges of "ambition," "drive," and "pushiness." But the biggest obstacle isn't the media or male colleagues (or even some of our fellow females). Worse than the culture's approach to women in power are our own fears about power: the fear that we're setting ourselves up for attack, the fear that we'll alienate others, the fear that we may actually become the caricature of the obnoxious, shrill, she-devil boss. All these fears manifest themselves in the fear of expressing ourselves. It's an internalized censorship of ambition. Which is all the worse because, now more than ever, we need women leaders to take us beyond the world of fear we live in. You can find many examples of how to do this in¬†Julia Boorstin's ‚ÄúWhen Women Lead‚Äù ‚Äî it‚Äôs filled with both research and stories from many of the top women leaders in business of how they fulfilled that ambition.#Leadership #Female #Leaders #Women #Business

Post Text: Our social media feeds are often a non-stop highlight reel of our successes. This week, I wanted to share a different kind of #TBT, one about failure. Maybe I should be looking at a different career.‚Äù Instead, I remember running out of money and walking, depressed, down St James Street in London and seeing a Barclays Bank. Even though I didn‚Äôt have any assets, the banker ‚Äì whose name was Ian Bell ‚Äì gave me a loan. It changed my life, because it meant I could keep things together for another, yes 13 rejections! And then I got an acceptance. It makes the point that failure isn‚Äôt the opposite of success, but, as my mother often said, a stepping stone to success. And by the way, I kept in touch with Ian Bell, and still send a holiday card every year. This photo was taken when I was living in London around that time. #Success #Failure #Rejection

Author: Arianna Huffington
Post Text: Much like snooze alarms themselves, the great Snooze Button Debate ‚Äì thought to be largely settled ‚Äì is ringing once again. In TIME magazine, Jamie Ducharme reports on a new study casting doubt on the view of many experts ‚Äì and this non-expert ‚Äì that hitting the snooze button isn‚Äôt great for your sleep. The study, published in the journal Sleep, was conducted by Stephen Mattingly, a serial snoozer and post-doctoral researcher at the University of Notre Dame. The results showed that snoozers didn‚Äôt sleep less in total or feel more tired during the day than non-snoozers. But, the study notes, snoozers were found to be sleeping more lightly before waking and had elevated resting heart rates, which suggests their stress responses were being set off in advance of their alarm being set off. Mattingly says that simply means they can break through their ‚Äúsleep inertia‚Äù more quickly. But as Kathryn Roecklein, a professor who researches sleep at the University of Pittsburgh, points out, there are better ways to do that, like turning on the lights when you wake up. The larger point is if you find you can‚Äôt get up when your alarm goes off, that‚Äôs a loud message your body is sending that you‚Äôre not getting enough sleep. And Roecklein notes that repeated snoozing in the morning can also make it harder to get to sleep at night and keep a consistent sleep schedule, which keeps our circadian rhythms in sync. So snoozers of the world unite ‚Äì and throw off your buttons ‚Äì you‚Äôve nothing to lose but lighter sleep, elevated heart rates and out-of-sync circadian rhythms! But if you must snooze, at least do it with a real alarm clock and not your phone, since charging it by your bed can cost you sleep on both ends of the night. https://lnkd.in/dVqqG8pN#Sleep #Snooze #Sleeping #TheSleepRevolution #TheSnoozeDebate

Post Text: Our long national nightmare is not over. Or, perhaps more accurately, our long national nightmare‚Äôs are not over. The tell is my misuse of the apostrophe, which, as evidenced by¬†this Axios piece¬†by Carly Mallenbaum, is still spreading. ‚ÄúIf you don't want to turn your grammar-nerd friends into grinches this¬†holiday season,‚Äù writes Mallenbaum, ‚Äúhere's a reminder: Avoid overusing apostrophes.‚Äù For example, holiday card signatures: ‚ÄúLove, the Smith‚Äôs,‚Äù vs. ‚ÄúLove, the Smiths.‚Äù¬† Yes, there are bigger problems in the world than one of our smallest punctuation marks, but this one is so stubborn, it‚Äôs enough to drive picky grammar nerds (PGNs, but definitely¬†not¬†PGN‚Äôs) insane. I first wrote about the apostrophe crisis back in 2005 when the headlines had constant mention of ‚ÄúWMD‚Äôs.‚Äù There were no WMDs, but there were definitely zombie apostrophes and nothing seems to be able to stop them from being deployed.¬†My crusade began in earnest when my daughter Isabella was in middle school and wrote an essay about a school camping¬†trip, which involved, as she wrote, a ‚Äúrope‚Äôs course.‚Äù I gently corrected her, and she responded by saying that, in fact, her teacher agreed with her. She kept the apostrophe and, sure enough, it went uncorrected by the teacher.¬†¬†Sure it‚Äôs minor, but it‚Äôs a grammar version of the broken windows theory. Once one broken grammar window becomes normalized, where does it end? Thanks to texting, we‚Äôve already done away with capitalization and punctuation at the end of sentences. Emojis are an invasive species we‚Äôve all accepted. But we have to draw the line somewhere. And the apostrophe isn‚Äôt decorative ‚Äì it actually has meaning.¬†So here we are, with our apostrodemic still raging, and one for which there‚Äôs apparently no vaccine. Since we humans seem to have proven ourselves incapable of using this punctuation tool responsibly, perhaps this is one of those beneficial humanity-enhancing uses for AI.¬†The¬†LLMs will do it for us. The only danger is that we have to make sure the texts they‚Äôre trained on don‚Äôt themselves have misused apostrophes ‚Äì otherwise we‚Äôll be headed for an AGI apocatastrophe. Author: Arianna Huffington
Post Text: As the death toll climbs in the tragedy of the Maui wildfires, one of the most heartbreaking failures is the warning sirens that were supposed to ring ‚Äî but didn‚Äôt. As the BBC reports, Maui has 80 outdoor sirens, tested monthly, intended to warn residents of tsunamis and other natural disasters. As the fast-moving fires swept across the island, these sirens failed to sound. Far too many human catastrophes result from warning signs being missed, going all the way back to the ancient world. At Pompeii, whose people were wiped out in the first century by a violent volcanic eruption, there had been many warning signs, including a severe earthquake, tremors, springs and wells that dried up, dogs that ran away and birds that no longer sang. And then the most obvious warning sign: columns of smoke belching out of Mount Vesuvius before the volcano blew its top, burying the city and its inhabitants under sixty feet of ash and volcanic rock. But the warning signs had been dismissed as ‚Äúnot particularly alarming.‚Äù In the face of tragedy, one of the best things we can do to feel less helpless is take action ‚Äî even in small ways. If you‚Äôd like to donate, this Forbes article includes several organizations currently accepting money and supplies: https://lnkd.in/demwTNpA#MauiFires #Community #Support #Action

He turned to it when he realized there were certain aspects of his life he couldn‚Äôt resolve, ‚Äúno matter how much plant medicine or other forms of medicine or exercise or podcasting or science or friendship or any of that‚Äù he did. For Huberman, it‚Äôs a way of ‚Äúunderstanding how I fit into this bigger picture.‚Äù And, he stresses, it doesn‚Äôt have to be about God in the traditional sense, ‚Äúbut if we don‚Äôt believe in something bigger than ourselves, we, at some level, will self-destruct. I really think so.‚ÄùExample three: closer to home, my own sister Agapi Stassinopoulos‚Äô book,¬†Speaking with Spirit: 52 Prayers to Guide, Inspire, and Uplift You. Post Text: Machine learning is all the rage, but how, exactly, do machines learn? The best way, it turns out, is to learn the way children do. This mirrors our own process. ‚ÄúWe need to start out as those crazy kids in the airport to become effective, intelligent adults,‚Äù writes Gopnik. ‚ÄúBut, of course, the children can only thrive if the grown-ups take care of them, too.‚Äù Which means the best AI will need adult supervision.
